description:
Algoriphagus taiwanensis is a species of bacteria that was first isolated from soil samples collected in Taiwan. It belongs to the genus Algoriphagus, which is a part of the phylum Bacteroidetes.

Algoriphagus taiwanensis is a Gram-negative, aerobic, and non-spore-forming bacterium. It is rod-shaped and exhibits gliding motility. The cells typically range in size from 0.3-0.6 μm in width and 1.2-3.0 μm in length.

Taxonomically, Algoriphagus taiwanensis is classified based on its 16S rRNA gene sequence analysis, which places it within the family Cytophagaceae. This species is known to grow optimally at temperatures around 30°C and at neutral pH levels.

Biochemically, Algoriphagus taiwanensis is able to hydrolyze various polysaccharides and is considered to be a heterotrophic bacterium, meaning it requires organic carbon sources for energy and growth. The exact ecological roles and functions of this species in its natural soil environment are still under investigation.
